The battle scenes are excellent, and very realistic, especially in "Loyalty" and "Duty" sea battles where we can see splinters splashes after explosions.The distinguished in the fifth sequel-"Mutiny" -that it makes you angry, whereas the sixth sequel- "Retribution"- makes you confuses.The great about "Retribution" the way captain James Sawyer provoking his first lieutenant Bukland while he was locked up, he remind me of Dr. Hannibal in the "Silence of the lambs".As I said in my review regarding "Horatio Hornblower - The New Adventures" which contains 2 DVDs "Loyalty" and "Duty", the early releases were on Full-Screen Format, then later releases were on Letter-Box Format.But at least "Horatio Hornblower - The New Adventures" both DVDs "Loyalty" and "Duty" were on the same format, but in "Horatio Hornblower Collector's Edition" "Loyalty" is Letter-Box Format and "Duty" is Full-Screen Format!May be they were in rush to release "Horatio Hornblower Collector's Edition" regardless the quality, and most of all the common sense, as both DVDs should be either in Full or Letter-Box Format.We love Hornblower, and Ioan Gruffudd (Horatio Hornblower) performance was excellent as always, he proved that he always conquer, in love and war.

reviewText: ***Since all viewers have different preferences in what they watch, this review is merely to document any content where someone, especially parents, may want to be aware of prior to watching. This is not a dismissal of the film, but rather just a resource. This review neither condemns nor condones any of the content listed below, but merely states it with an unbiased eye.**Language:- In every movie episode, there is a LARGE amount of language.- Crude/suggestive references are made quite a few times.Flesh Flashes/Sexual Content:-In nearly the opening scene of the first movie, men and women are seen in the background cavorting and fondling.In the movie called "The Duchess and the Devil", a woman seductively invites a man to sleep with her.-In the movie called "Mutiny," the main character Horatio Hornblower is seen naked from the knees up from behind.-In the movie called "Retribution," in the middle of a pile of dead bodies, one of the bodies is seen entirely without pants from behind.-In the movie called "Loyalty," a female prisoner seduces a prison guard (a ploy to steal his keys). The scene contains necking, fondling, her legs wrapped around his body, and a zoomed-in view of his hand pulling up her dress and grabbing at her naked backside, which gives a camera shot of her thigh and a very small amount of pubic area.-The women in the movies usually bare a revealing amount of cleavage.Violence:-You see stabbing. You see shooting. You see blood shooting out from the head of a man who just shot himself. You see a lot of brutal fist-fights. Two people are caned/whipped. It's violent throughout the movies, but not barbaric.**UPDATE: if you feel this review is offensive somehow (refer to comments), please re-read the opening paragraph of this review. Once again, this review is not slandering, condemning or judging this film, but is merely a statement of fact as to what can be expected in watching this film, written with parents in mind. This is a well-made, acclaimed film with much to offer as far as entertainment and historical exposure. The purpose of this review is not to pass judgment or to force a legalistic view on anyone. It is merely a statement of fact, not an enforcement of a particular conservative view or ideology. This review neither says you should or shouldn't watch this film nor does it pass any judgment on the content listed above, it merely states what a viewer may expect to see or hear. Please take that into consideration prior to leaving comments.**

reviewText: A&E; does C.S. Forester's tales of Horatio Hornblower proud.  Each of the eight discs in this set of made-for-TV movies are outstanding pieces of work.The main character in the series is Horatio Hornblower.  Hornblower is a reluctant hero who acts mainly to prove to himself that he is not a coward, just as he is described in Forester's books.  As Hornblower acts he learns to become an effective officer and leader in the heyday of the Royal Navy's age of sail.The tales ring true since many of the episodes are filmed on the Black Sea aboard a newly constructed square rigger.  The character development is outstanding, and there is not a weak link in the casts from the main character, Hornblower, to officers such as Mr. Bush, Mr. Kennedy, and ordinary seamen such as Stiles, MacElroy, or my personal favorite - Matthews.The cinematography is outstanding, the storylines are surprisingly faithful to Forester's books, and the live filming and special effects involving miniatures of sailing ships is seemless.I have read the entire set of CS forester's Hornblower books, and I have watched each of these 8 films several times.  They are simply some of the most outstanding films I have ever seen.  The quality of these films rely on outstanding acting, great character development, and great pacing.You may be interested to know that my 16-year old son, who tends to be impressed by films that employ digital special effects heavily (e.g., Spiderman, Lord of the Rings, etc.) includes these films among his favorite.  If that's not an endorsement, I don't know what is ;)This boxed set is definitely the way to go to get all of the episodes in this series.The only regret I have about this series is that A&E; does not plan to make any more!  If only...if only!  These movies take us up through Forester's books to the point where Hornblower would be made a captain, but that's where they stop.This series should be of particular interest to history buffs, people with interest in the age of sail, fans of C.S. Forester, as well as fans of Ioan Gruffudd or other cast members.5 stars all the way, and I'd award 10 to this series if I could!

reviewText: There are 8 Horatio Hornblower movies altogether and I thoroughly enjoyed them from start to finish. Please bring back Horatio Hornlower!!!!!

reviewText: This review contains my feelings about a wide variety of efforts to portray the life and times of one of my favorite fictional characters. Horatio Hornblower was first introduced to me in High School when I found three of his books in the H.S. library: "Beat to Quarters", "Ship of the Line", and "Flying Colours."  I read all 3 books several times. I remember seeing the Hollywood film "Captain Horatio Hornblower" [starring Gregory Peck and Virginia Mayo] in theaters, I think in the early 1950s, and I later purchased it as a VHS tape. It was among my favorite "movies" as a boy. Tapes are known to break, or otherwise become tangled, so when I saw that the film was available as a DVD I immediately purchased it in that format.I'm sure that it goes without saying that C.S. Forester's "Horatio Hornblower" is one of my favorite fictional characters. [Along with  Bernard Cornwell's Richard Sharpe, and I wonder if it is pure coincidence that both characters are from the Napoleonic era?]  As for Hornblower, to really get to know him, I highly recommend the Emmy Award winning series "Horatio Hornblower: Collector's Edition." This comes in a boxed set of 8 DVDs and portrays Hornblower's early career in the British Navy. Ioan Gruffudd is excellent  in the title role. I found it easy to make the transference between Peck and Gruffudd. I own and have read all 11 of C.S. Forester's books dealing with Hornblower's entire career in the British navy from Midshipman to Admiral. I highly recommend any and all books, tapes and DVDs that chronicle Horatio Hornblower's career. I've just recently completed reading all 11 books in sequence for the 2nd time, and I recommend reading and watching all volumes and films in sequence when possible. [I mean by that, story-line sequence, not the order in which they were written.]One thing that I particularly liked about this main character is that Hornblower is portrayed by Forester as a believable, complex character who is at the same time intelligent and heroic, while also exhibiting less noble but very human qualities. For example, even as commander of a ship, he's still subject to sea-sickness on occasion.  A true hero, "warts and all!"  Both Gruffudd and Peck capture on film the varying qualities of this very complex man. Gruffudd's portrayal of Hornblower as a young man, just beginning his naval career is superb. Warning: the 8 disc Collectors Edition has episodes that are not included in the books. Don't let that bother you... they still have merit.  If C.S. Forester were still living, I feel sure that he would be very pleased with the ways in which his hero's qualities have been portrayed. I highly recommend any and all books and films that feature C.S. Forester's "Horatio Hornblower" or Bernard Cornwell's "Richard Sharpe".

reviewText: I think that almost any novel (or series of novels) which achieves 'favorite' status is at a competitive disadvantage when turned into a film.  The most notable exceptions are works written, either consciously or not, with a screenplay in mind (I'm convinced Michael Crichton ONLY writes screenplays).I think it safe to assume that C. S. Forester was not writing with the screen, either large or small, in mind so I have to say that this series is hands down the best miniseries ever produced from another media.The series is well paced, the characters well developed and wonderfully cast, the action scenes excellently shot, but to my way of thinking the series best feature is the development and maturation of the character of Hornblower himself..I've always been a fan of `coming of age' films (my all time favorite - A Bronx Tale), but to watch the growing relationships which Hornblower develops with Mathews, Styles, Captain Foster, Taping, and particularly with Captain/Admiral Sir Edward Pellew is truly a joy.Ioan Gruffudd's portrayal produces a character which every guy should secretly want to be and which every woman should want to hook up with.  This series is a `must have' for every film library.
summary: I think Forester would have approved.

reviewText: What can I say that has not already been said about these movies? A couple of buddies and I usually get together at my house on Thursday nights to watch films. I had purchased the first set of Horatio movies and we watched the first movie one Thursday, we were really blown away. The characters, the events, the ships everything rocked. Since then we have seen all the movies and we really cannot choose which one we like best.Something we do agree on is that Horatio is the kind of guy we would all like to be like. He is the quintessential guy: strong in character, a born leader, not afraid to show emotion when called for, loyal, etc. You really have to give Ioan (the actor who is Horatio) his props. With any other actor this type of character might seem too perfect, yet you don't feel that at all. On the contrary you seem to see him as even more believable.The movies show how Horatio goes from a midshipman (very low in the order of importance) and his hardships to prove himself and climbing the ladder to captain.

reviewText: If you want to see how people lived on a British warship during Napoleonic war, this tv series is for you.  The acting is average. There are a lot of twists. The costumes look authentic. The boats, especially French boats are not shown in details, just briefly. It's the same for  the fighting scenes. They're very short. Most of the times, only things on the British sides are depicted not on the French side. The hand-to-hand fighting is left much to be desired. All these exposes the small budget of the movie.It's a drama but somehow it does not appeal to me. It's still worth renting for curiosity.

reviewText: This collection appeals to me on many levels.  The sheer humanity of the characters, the authenticity of the set, or maybe just the fact that I forget that I am staring at a television set when I am experiancing this series.  History gives us facts and dates, but C. S. Forrester gave us the Blood, Sweat and sinew of life on an English Vessal in her Majesty's Service.  This is faithful to that vision without seeming dated or stiff. The collector's edition also takes a litle less space due to it's clever packaging.  I wish they had thought of this when I first began buying DVDs.  Theoretically, they shouldn't take up any more space than a compact disk, but at least in this case, the content more than makes up for it.
summary: This Is Well Worth Some Space on your Shelf

reviewText: Forester has remained one of my favorite authors, and stands alone at the top of the nautical fiction heap. While Patrick O'Brian has received a considerable following, with Master and Commander garnering popularity, he's nearly unreadable in comparison. I believe that many people are merely unaware of Forester's cleverness and depth, and just choose what they see available. As for this series? Ioan Gruffudd, all other actors, and director Adrew Grieve interpreted the spirit of the writing exceedingly well. This series is a joy to watch and own.For anyone who has been captivated by this A&E; series, created back in the good old days when A&E; was all about arts and entertainment, I would recommend reading the eleven books in the Hornblower series. Forester has also crafted other exciting and intelligent books outside the Napoleonic era. "African Queen" was made into a great Bogart movie. Some investigation will lead you to a wealth of reading material, although many of these books are sadly out of print. The good news is that Forester was wildly popular in his day, and that many of his books pop up frequently in used book stores.For those who are contemplating the purchase of this series? This is just about as good as it gets. Immerse yourself in Horblower's quirky honor, see depraved, impressed men battling rats with their teeth, and see blood spilling from the scuppers.
summary: The Genius Of C. S. Forester

reviewText: I've read every one of C.S. Forester's Hornblower novels, and I have to say that although I enjoyed the books tremendously, I liked this adaptation even more. While Forester's novels were wonderful, they lacked the heightened drama that was packed into each episode in this series.  The characters, especially Kennedy (whom some of you may recognize from Battlestar Galactica), Styles, Matthews and the redoubtable Pellew truly came to life. In many cases the plots were condensed, which added to their dramatic impact.  The writing was crisp, the acting superb, and the filming atmospheric. All in all, I don't think you can do better for seafaring adventure! There is no doubt in my mind that Forester would have loved this adaptation. The only pity is that there wasn't enough funding to continue the series.
summary: Glorious adventures on the high seas!!

reviewText: To Hornblower aficionados the departures from C.S. Forester's plotting may seem a little offensive (or a lot, to the purist), but some of the changes worked rather well. For instance, the use of flashback from a Jamaican military court to cover most of the Lieutenant Hornblower plot was well done, allowing gaps in the story line to be not so jarring. Otherwise, most plot alterations in the interests of time compression aren't too serious, and all but the most serious Hornblowerite shouldn't have too much trouble with them. And by way of compensation, the producers do an excellent job with ship models that look very realistic in action, generally accurate costumery and very nice location settings. The acting is good overall, with very little of the stiffness that so often accompanies period pieces.Two irritations, however, one of them minor but the other perplexing.First, in the early going young Hornblower takes a prize ship into action flying false colors. Hornblowerites (and anyone else familiar with the customs of maritime warfare in those days) know that it was a legitimate ruse de guerre to fly false colors up to a point, but before opening fire it was mandatory to hoist the national colors. Failure to do so was an act of piracy under the conventions of the time, to say nothing of unforgivably dishonorable. Unlike the book, Mr. Midshipman Hornblower, Hornblower fails to raise the true colors throughout the engagement, and when questioned about it dismisses it with a shrug and a "whatever works" comment. That may appeal to certain viewers in this age of the anti-hero swashbuckling macho man, but it would probably have ruined the career of a naval officer in Hornblower's day, despite the success of the action.Second, the assault on the Spanish fortress in the Lieutenant Hornblower segment departs entirely from C.S. Forester's story, and the result is a shambles. The "real" attack was a straightforward dawn assault filled with risk and action. There were no deserters prior to the attack. There were no explosives smuggled into serendipitously discovered tunnels. The island's rebel forces made no appearance at all. Taken together with a tangle of subplots involving hostilities among the British officers and warrants, the whole scene was an almost indecipherable mess.To return to the positive, the Captain Pellew character does an excellent job, neatly capturing the delicate balance between fondness for young Hornblower and the sternness necessary to rein in the latter's impulsiveness. Pellew several times gives Hornblower a look that speaks volumes: You have the makings of a fine officer, but you've a lot to learn.The Hornblower purist will have a hard time gulping through the numerous departures from Forester's wonderful stories, but I think it's worth the effort -and the money- to enjoy a very good production.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I tried this series on a friend's recommendation. Have since recommended it at least a dozen times and each time have made a new Horatio fan. What's not to love?The films follow the adventurous rising career of Horatio Hornblower, a young British naval officer, as he progresses from ignorant, seasick midshipman to more-than-competent captain of his own crew of loyal men. Horatio always does the right thing, but not without self-doubt and painful consequence. His charm is in his integrity and his commitment to principles long left by the wayside in contemporary filmmaking. Its even easy to forgive the stilted nature of the action sequences, because the real action takes place in the brave hearts of our hero and his friends and besides, how much can one expect from men who must do their fighting in heels?The ships, of course, are beauty to behold, as are the costumes. Everyone puts in fine performances, though Ioan Gruffud as Horatio and Robert Lindsey as Pellew are well beyond the pale.Highly recommended to everyone who enjoys a film with the stoic qualities of heroism and loyalty, embedded in a fine historical setting.

reviewText: Although a bit uneven, on the whole, this is a very enjoyable series of films.The first 4 movies stand out as the best.  The first, "The Duel" is an introduction to our young hero, and his hard introduction to the ways of the sea and sailors.  It has the best battle at sea footage of the entire series.The second entry, "The Fire Ships" also includes some fine special effects work, and is possibly the best movie in the series."The Duchess and the Devil" and "The Wrong War" end the first series of movies.  The former is finely done, perhaps more "real" than any of the other episodes, and you never know how this one will end.  The latter is still very entertaining, and gives us more of the war on the land than any other movie.  The love interest, unfortunately, ends the same way here as it does in most dramatic movies of this kind.Set aboard the "Indefatigable", the series is in full sail.  Ioan Gruffudd is very good as our hero, although he appears a bit older than 17, as he supposedly starts out.  Robert Lindsay is the captain with which everyone would wish to sail.Produced later, and set about 7 years after the first movies, now aboard another ship, "The Mutiny" and "Retribution" are actually two parts to the same movie.  Therefore, allow yourself time to watch these two close together. Although done well again, there is something unsettling about any movie that is about the removal of a captain.  David Warner does a fine job as the famous captain of the "Renown", who's more brutal than normal ways are fueled by growing paranoia.  But when it get to fighting (mostly, again, on land), the movie takes off.The final two movies, "Loyalty" and "Duty" are closely related (similar themes with one unresolved issue from the first leading into the second).  Let me just say this "issue" did not add to the story as the writers had hoped.  Although entertaining, it appears the budget might have been a bit worse, for the special effects, namely explosions, were horribly done.  Another point of contention is the now Captain Hornblower still playing too much the hero.  He simply doesn't delegate some matters that most captains would have delegated, particularly when he had such a good first lieutenant.Quality wise, I was very pleased with the series, especially since this was a made-for-TV series, without the big Hollywood budgets.  It's not "Master and Commander", nor was it meant to be.  It was a bit disappointing after "The Duel" that we didn't get a really good, multiple ship fight at sea.DVD extras were good, but not great.  There definately could have been more cast/director interviews, but those they had were entertaining.All-in-all a very good value that left you wanting for more!
summary: Few made for TV series can match! (None on free TV)

reviewText: Given the title and subject matter- seaman- you might think that this is the latest release from Falcon (and I'm sure that they or another adult studio has certainly released their version of these classics). You'd be wrong. Horatio Hornblower is instead an epic story of honor, loyalty, and duty. Featuring bloody battles, incredible adventures, and a cast of characters as good as any ever imagined, it's no wonder that this Emmy Award-winning series got raves from critics and the general public alike.Based on the novels by C.S. Forester, A&E;'s Horatio Hornblower was a made-for-TV series that ran from 1998-2003. The eight individual films that make up this Collector's Edition chronicle the unlikely rise of young Horatio from lowly midshipman to powerful commander, during the early years of the Napoleonic Wars. The stories are engaging and entertaining, the production grand and lavish, and the overall result brilliant.Nothing was spared in making these films and they're worth watching for the visuals alone. (It's also interesting to note that no computer generated effects were used, which makes the intensity of the battles that much more exciting to watch.) That being said, the story lines are also enthralling, the characters fully developed, and the performances powerful all around. This is a series that will keep anyone engaged; from small children to grandparents.Each film (or "episode") runs about an hour and a half, and each can stand independent of the others. Having said that, if you're going to watch them all, why not watch them in order and add that much more to the experience? The underlying theme to all episodes is strong personal ethics, against all odds, and while that may sound frighteningly preachy, I assure you that the films are not.These films/episodes have been released previously a number of times, both individually and in sets, including a Collector's Edition that was released in 2005. If you own the 2005 set, do not buy this new set; as far as I can tell, other than extremely minor changes to the packaging, this is the same product.Included films/episodes are :: The Duel, The Fire Ships, The Duchess and the Devil, The Wrong War, The Mutiny, Retribution, Loyalty, and Duty.SPECIAL FEATURESAs if eight films spanning more than 13 hours weren't enough, the special features and extras are also copious. Two of the episodes (Loyalty and Duty) feature accompanying Filmmaker Commentary, which offers an incredibly thought-provoking and historically interesting look into the making of the series, the background, and the adaptation from page to screen. An Exclusive Interview with star Ioan Gruffudd is just as spellbinding (and with the latter you get the extra bonus of his incredibly good looks!).Three Bonus Programs (England's Royal Warships, Sail 2000: Aboard the Eagle, and The Making of Horatio Hornblower) give an exclusive look at English ships from the past to the present, with fascinating descriptions and documentary footage on how these amazing machines are manned and run, as well as the incredible feats they're capable of. If this isn't enough for you, check out the Guide to Royal Warships, Nautical Terms and Definitions, and Interactive 3-D Naval Cannon, and you'll be a master seaman in no time!For those interested in more background on the original author, a featurette entitled About C.S. Forester is especially interesting, as is the C.S. Forester Biography.Cast and Crew Biographies are also included, as is a Photo Gallery.The special features presented with this set are indeed incredible, although I wouldn't recommend sitting down and watching them all at once. In fact, it's best absorbed (and more interesting) if you watch one film/episode and one (or part of one) special feature, then take some time to digest and reflect upon them before moving on to another helping.Final answer :: If you've not seen them, this is an extremely entertaining and wonderfully produced series, not to mention an incredibly good buy. If you own the previously released Collector's Edition however, skip this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Horatio Hornblower is an exciting adventure movie.  All of the characters are realistic and the story is well written. This is another great British film!  The Hollywood made films often seem to depend upon big name stars that are often miscast in their roles.This story takes place during the war between France and England at the time of Napoleon Bonaparte. Horatio Hornblower is a man who has risen up in the ranks of the English navy to the role of Captain.  He's an intelligent young man who pays attention to details and knows the strengths and weaknesses of his crew. He's also very likeable and honest which gains him the trust and respect of his peers and superior officers.  He's smart, but not overly confident and his humanity shows when he doubts himself at different times in the story.The actors are professional and not just pretty faces.  My husband and I both enjoyed this movie.  I highly recommend it to adults and children alike.  The filming is beautiful and the story can be viewed by young people without concern for content.

reviewText: JUST DO IT!!!!!The 8 dvd COLLECTOR'S EDITION of Horatio Hornblower is the only way to go in watching the heroic adventures of this amazing character from the C.S.Forester novels.Each of the 8 episodes,100 minutes in length, are chock full of naval history,fascinating characters and the superior acting of Ioan Gruffudd (pronounced Yo-an Griffith) and veteran stage idol Sir Robert Lindsay.We watch our hero grow from a "wet-behind-the-ears" English midshipman to full fledge Captain.Hornblower and his fellow shipmates become endearing friends to the viewer .You will find that as soon as you finish one episode you will want to pop in another.Ioan Gruffudd is undoubtedly one of the most accomplished actors in the world today,and he inhabits this character's skin to a tee! All 8 episodes are crystal clear in picture,beautifully coloured,subtitled (if you feel it necessary to navigate naval terminology and various English accents),perfect dolby surround sound,correct aspect ratio, with lots of neat interactive menues plus a wonderful interview with Gruffudd who is a really neat "actor's actor".Each dvd comes in a slim case and the entire collection is housed in a sturdy outer case.This is an extremely well made box set and is definitely worth the price.
summary: The Collector's  8 DVD BOX SET is the way to go FIRST CLASS

reviewText: I'm a bit surprised to see all the other reviewers drooling all over this DVD series with 5 stars.  I suspect none of them have read the books.It does have some good qualities.  The casting and acting are good.  It is cool getting to see the costumes, ships, and models.  However, contrary to the ship model documentary, it's actually pretty easy to tell you are looking at models much of the time, especially from the scale of the fire and water.My biggest problem with the films is the way they butchered CS Forester's stories, especially films #5 thru 8 which are maybe 25% Forester at most.  The stories themselves are practically action-adventure movies in print form as it is, so I don't understand the screenplay writers' motivation.Foremost, the changes they have made diminish the uniqueness of the Hornblower saga by injecting large doses of standard Hollywood-style melodrama.  Characters are added to provide extra love and friendship interest, foreshadowed treachery, and tragic deaths.  The Mutiny and Retribution stories are even turned into standard courtroom dramas with flashbacks.  Things are rearranged such that you are less able to witness Hornblower's daring and ingenuity for yourself.  Instead you mostly get told about it, and see it second-hand in other characters' congratulations.The other big issue with the story changes is that they magnify historical anachronisms.  For instance, a character drinking from a flask or pouring a drink is depicted as nearly sinister, whereas the standard sailor's issue on a ship at that time was about 11 beers and 5 shots of rum per day.  A few whacks with a rattan cane is depicted as nearly deadly and deeply disturbing to the officers, whereas in reality crippling floggings with a cat-o-nine of a hundred lashes or more was common - a dozen lashes that would make the rattan caning look like a massage were standard for being a little too drunk at the wrong time.  In general, the characters are emotionally effusive in a way that is out of character with the time and the way behavior was depicted in the books - especially Hornblower's.Overall, I think it is pretty good - not a waste of time or a few bucks at all, but somewhat disappointing.  If you are really interested, I recommend it, but you should definitely read the books first.
summary: Screenplay definitely NOT by CS Forester!

reviewText: The thing I love about series like this, is that they allow you to be sucked in to the entire story and you sit & watch as the characters unfold in realistic fashion and move on to great accomplishments.  It's always so satisfying to watch something with the width & breadth of scope that HH has & is executed wonderfully.You do not have to like ships to like this series, but it helps.  You do not have to enjoy period pieces, though that also helps.  And you do not have to know the particulars of British and French history, though I will tell you that you need a rudimentary knowledge : ie, what was happening in France around 1793 when "The Duel" begins such as the reign of terror, Napolean's later scrabble for power, & how the outcome declared the British as the power of the seas--uncontested.  Though you should know that Britain has been a strong naval power since their defeat of the Spanish Armada in Elizabethan times, but the Napoleanic wars sealed the deal, so to speak.  And the military also started becoming a more reputable way to earn social income & respectibility (see Austen, the queen of respectibility & "Persuasion).Socially, of course, you could throw in the British mentality toward the French, the barbaric nature of it, the flouting of tradition, the willful slaughter of thousands. (Hmm, though England's own beheading of a monarch was not SO far behind them) But on a tangent, I think it was that England felt kin to France; they'd been fighting for centuries with several instanes of cross-polination of the nobility in their ancestry. And the terror unsettled stolid British souls, seeing their own possible fate at in the French degeneration of rational self into the rampant rage of the sensibilities. The bloodiness was a little too much for the Brits.So that's all you need.  Really.  Military historians will delight in the parallel occurrences of true events, but for the rest of us to enjoy the story & the acting, you just need a quick background check.I warn you, you'll get sucked in quick!Enjoy.
summary: I concur with everyone else! GREAT series

reviewText: Watching these eight splendid episodes of "Horatio Hornblower," it's easy to see where "Star Trek" and "Star Trek: The Next Generation" got so much inspiration from, both for characters and plots. Or maybe it's a case of cross-pollination, where a film version of the Hornblower novels inadvertently borrows back from Star Trek, thus closing the circle of inspiration. The wrapping-up of almost every episode with a thoughtful conversation between Hornblower and Pellew isn't in the novels as far as I know, and certainly smacks of the Kirk/Spock or Picard/Riker chemistry. In fact there is a scene (in "The Wrong War") in which Pellew compliments Hornblower on his "logical deduction" and where Gruffudd seems to play his character with a definite touch of Leonard Nimoy's Spock (eyebrow movements and all).  Those two actors and the writers certainly knew what they were up to!The first four episodes (1999) are particularly great, as they make heavy use of a real ship, the Grand Turk, for shipboard scenes. In the later episodes, particularly 7 and 8 (2003), there is more CGI and a diminished sense of reality, which unfortunately puts those episodes in the vicinity ofThe Perfect StormandMaster and Commander - The Far Side of the World: actors in a green-screen water tank getting doused via water slides from all directions. The cliché Hollywood storm scene, in other words. I like the reality of the first 4 parts with sunshine and the sense of being on a real ship (because most of the time, you are) much better.The adaptation, especially in the later episodes, is sometimes a little too liberal in its deviations from the books and occasionally soap-operatic (e.g., the characters of Wolfe and Captain Sawyer). So in the unlikely event that more episodes should get produced at some point, hopefully the writers will refrain from making too many unnecessary changes. But otherwise this is an excellent series of movies (mini-series really doesn't do it justice!) that certainly warrants multiple viewings to catch all the details, or salivate a little over the cute midshipman/lieutenant du jour, such as Jamie Bamber, Terence Corrigan, Christian Coulson or Jonathan Forbes. A particular standout is Paul Copley as the bosun, who couldn't be more different in his rle here from his character inQueer as Folk UK. A wonderful yarn, especially after the lackluster and unexciting "Master and Commander"...

reviewText: Evocative series that had a well deserved Emmy and focuses on the early naval period of the Napoleonic Wars.  Horatio Hornblower is well played by Ioan Gruffudd (this was before he got main roles in lots of feature films) , who is something of the perfect junior officer: loyal, dutiful, well mannered and almost always does the right thing.  The real highlights though are that they get the period right with the ship designs and especially the costumes (notice the old time officers have different angled naval hats to the younger ones).  Unfortunately, each episode was so expensive that they couldn't afford to do a second season.  Gruffudd has spoken about doing a later feature film that follows after the series.  CHARACTERS: A minus; SETTING: A  STORY/PLOT POINTS: B plus to A minus; OVERALL GRADE: A minus to A  WHEN WATCHED: September to November 2010.

reviewText: I loved this series and waited for two or more years for the price to come down. I was so excited when it did. I bought 3 complete sets. reviewText: This superb series continues to inspire.  With Ioan Gruffud as Hornblower we are assured of a first rate item.  The beauty of this series is in the production value and fine acting.  Sets and unforms are correct and change in historical fashion.  Characters are not your standard one-dimensional types we usually get from Hollywood these days.  These are real human beings with complexity.  At first a character may come acorss as a snob or trouble maker only to surprise us with later turn of events.  This is what true character development is about.  So much could be learned by film producers intent are creating historical drama.  They should pay attntion to etail.This series should serve as an example of how an historical epic can be beautiflly and correctly brought to screen.  Screen writing is not over the top.  Action and situations are constantly based on the reality of the times they portray.  There are no Hollywood exaggerations and simplistic good and bad guy situations.  No Political Correct messages that producers wish to impart as propaganda.  Special effects are not over the top but are certainly fine. The music is sweeping and near perfect for the series. This is a production that prides itself on fine acting instead of mindless action!In short this is how every period drama should be produced.  Ioan Gruffud brings a charm and determined innocense to his Hornblower.  We see the character adapt and grow before our eyes.  This young Welsh actor has a brilliant future before him.  Its been a few years since the last episodes were done.  Let us hope that A&E; will continue to inspire us with this wonderful series.

reviewText: Horatio Hornblower (Ioan Gruffudd) is an Emmy award winning TV mini movie series that sets sail for all around quality entertainment. Hornblower is based on C.S. Foresters popular literature centered on Naploenoic wars and particular the British Royal naval aspect of it. This series is the most complete exploit into 18th century (late 17th century as well) British Royal naval life for the small screen. The series focus is always surrounding Hornblower (fictional character) a young man steadfast in his convictions to do what is right and his climb on the British Royal Navy seaman ladder. This all inclusive experience also spends ample time exploring the trials of being an able seaman aboard a British ship of war. Hornblower journey involves a plethora of obstacles whether he is cramming for the Lieutenant exam, dealing with a cruel seasoned midshipman who has a strong taste for duel's or engaged in vicious naval combat with the frogs (French). Other fan favorites are the highly competent and sapient Captain Pellew (Robert Lindsay), the reliable seaman Matthews (Paul Copley), Styles (Sean Gilder) who is also a staunch ally for Hornblower on top of being tough in a fight and last but not least Archie Kennedy (Jamie Bamber) Horatio's cohort, equal and true friend.Stories (character driven): Each movie in this series tackles a fresh conundrum/snare for Hornblower to get untangle from. Hornblower time and again will be tested on his wit plus craftiness to survive and hopefully be promoted. On top of that there is usually some interesting new aspect to seaman ship and naval warfare of the day displayed. The Hornblower series has a fluid progression from a young midshipman barely able to hold down his lunch down when faring rough seas. To a calm calculating Hornblower seasoned in giving as well as receiving orders. There's cliff hangers galore along with heart felt camaraderie that holds our cast and these many stories together. Each story demonstrates human character well along with honor, courage, Brit humor and stern leadership.Acting (solid): Ioan Gruffudd was born to play Hornblower. He plays him with honesty, inner strength and all the subtle nuances that really made Hornblower into a hit series. The rest of the cast is fantastic and really hold this series to high quality of acting that built up interesting deeply motivated characters to watch on the small screen.Music (strong): The music fits the time and era as well as sets the moods efficiently.Special effects/costume design (mostly well crafted): The effects don't compete well against its big screen cousin Master and Commander (Russell Crowe, another Naploenoic wars high sea adventure) when in comparison. There is plenty of cannon fire smoke, musket shooting and second rate explosions. War wounds are also second rate typically displayed by simple stained blood on the outfits. The effects do get the job done and never looks campy or silly. The effects are overall really good and did enhance the drama. The costumes are authentic and detailed. The real ships are magnificent and are up to scale. Many scenes involving multiple ships use high end models and this mostly goes unnoticed.Special Features(Fun and imformative):This section involves bits of the cast sounding off, an indepth look into Royal Navey life of the day and how modern ships compare to those of our past. I learned where many saying come from. For instance son of gun, learning the ropes and many more.Last take (classic A&E; show): Must see for any fans of the A & E channel movies, Naploenoic wars, History in general or those who enjoy a show with great acting. This is a great family show due to its mostly tame language and low graphic nature. I'm sure some people don't like this one but I really don't understand why.
summary: Hornblower the hero of his day
Title: N/A

reviewText: Our whole family has watched this together more than once.  This is a wonderful period drama, full of honor, loyalty, and friendship.  There are some very difficult scenes, however, involving whipping and wartime atrocities that may not be suitable for younger children, regardless of how historically accurate they may be. For teens, however, it can be a good family viewing experience, with enough history and excitement--and a little romance, for all.

reviewText: Hornblower is the most fun we've had in a long while. Plus you learn all kinds of things you didn't know before.  We saw part of it at our parents' house, came home and had to buy it.  Now we have loaned it to our son and his wife.  This is a great show for all adults!

reviewText: First let me admit, I've not read the books. That's probably why I like it more than those who have. I enjoy the development of the character from midshipman to commander, from boy to man. Yet all throughout he maintains a high standard of conduct and this quality earns him the respect of friends and enemies alike. Sometimes the episodes lose steam, but the overall series satisfied me.
